data.title: Fix issue #14109 and #13978
data.body:
â€¦b.com/atom/atom/issues/13978

First argument to dialog.showSaveDialog() needs to be a BrowserWindow

https://github.com/electron/electron/blob/master/docs/api/dialog.md
https://github.com/electron/electron/blob/master/lib/browser/api/dialog.js

### Requirements

* Filling out the template is required. Any pull request that does not include enough information to be reviewed in a timely manner may be closed at the maintainers' discretion.
* All new code requires tests to ensure against regressions

### Description of the Change

This should fix some regression introduced by commit https://github.com/atom/atom/commit/c6cae5b8fdfea982084b068a0b38a7c988c52f51 related to `showSaveDialog` causing things such "Save As", "Save as HTML" to not work properly (default filename "Untitled" and default path missing when it should be autofilled with more "reasonable" ones--e.g. original filename and path). 

This commit fixes the erroneous usage in [`src/main-process/atom-window.coffee#L268`](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/c6cae5b8fdfea982084b068a0b38a7c988c52f51/src/main-process/atom-window.coffee#L268) introduced in commit https://github.com/atom/atom/commit/c6cae5b8fdfea982084b068a0b38a7c988c52f51
```coffeescript
dialog.showSaveDialog(this, params)
```

Here, `this` refers to an instance of AtomWindow, when the function `dialog.showSaveDialog` requires the first argument to be a BrowserWindow [`electron/lib/browser/api/dialog.js#L24`](https://github.com/electron/electron/blob/master/lib/browser/api/dialog.js#L24). 

So I believe the fix is simply 
```coffeescript
dialog.showSaveDialog(@browserWindow, params)
```

This is consistent with with the function binding usage in [`src/main-process/atom-window.coffee#L86@c6cae5b`](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/c6cae5b8fdfea982084b068a0b38a7c988c52f51/src/main-process/atom-window.coffee#L86) and with the **old** working function `showSaveDialog` in [`src/application-delegate.coffee#L158`](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/ae9d949ee4e199d1884bed89083196fa375bbd34/src/application-delegate.coffee#L158)

<!--

We must be able to understand the design of your change from this description. If we can't get a good idea of what the code will be doing from the description here, the pull request may be closed at the maintainers' discretion. Keep in mind that the maintainer reviewing this PR may not be familiar with or have worked with the code here recently, so please walk us through the concepts.

-->

### Alternate Designs

N/A
<!-- Explain what other alternates were considered and why the proposed version was selected -->

### Why Should This Be In Core?

Bug fix.
<!-- Explain why this functionality should be in atom/atom as opposed to a package -->

### Benefits

Fixes bug (and see applicable issues)
<!-- What benefits will be realized by the code change? -->

### Possible Drawbacks

I cannot think of any at this moment.
<!-- What are the possible side-effects or negative impacts of the code change? -->

### Applicable Issues

- https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/14109
- https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/13978

data.title: Assign `Package.prototype.mainModulePath` eagerly for preloaded packages
data.body:
Many packages currently use this instance variable instead of calling `Package.prototype.getMainModulePath`. With this pull request we will eagerly compute such variable for preloaded packages too and therefore prevent third party packages that rely on this implementation detail from breaking.

/cc: @Ben3eeE who noticed this. Can you confirm this fixes the issue you experienced? Thanks!

data.title: Blurred screen when Windows dialog is moved around
data.body:
# ATOM Test

## Environment

- Version:  ATOM 1.15 X64
- OS: Win 7

## Issue

When saving a file, if the `Save As...` dialog is moved, the blured screen is frustrating.
![1](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/14267903/24583414/c3561088-1716-11e7-8e5d-e82f7480ae12.jpg)

data.title: Data loss when adding and removing project folders
data.body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

-->

### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=âœ“&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

There are already lots of unsaved buffer loss related issues, mostly of files with no project folder. However, this data loss scenario can also happen to a file with a project folder, without unusual or unintended behaviors such as crashing Atom, opening multiple windows of Atom, etc. It can be reproduced by the following steps.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Open Atom with project folder A and make some change. Be sure that the changes are not saved.
2. Close Atom.
3. Open Atom with project folder B.
4. Add project folder A, and then remove project folder B.
5. Close Atom.
6. Open Atom with project folder A. (Or possibly with no project folder)
7. Now the changes are gone!

**Expected behavior:** The changes must be preserved at a certain step. If Atom handles unsaved buffers separate from project folders, the changes should be shown in step 3. This was what I expected (as Sublime Text does) before I search for the related issues and find out that Atom integrates the editor's state with project folders. Since Atom integrates them, the changes in step 1 may be expected reappear in either step 4 (when adding project folder A) or step 6.

**Actual behavior:** Data loss

**Reproduces how often:** Always

### Versions

You can get this information from copy and pasting the output of `atom --version` and `apm --version` from the command line. Also, please include the OS and what version of the OS you're running.

Atom    : 1.15.0  
Electron: 1.3.13  
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82  
Node    : 6.5.0

data.title: The build instructions for Arch Linux demand installing the non existing packages libX11-devel and libxkbfile-devel
data.body:
In the [build instructions for Linux](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/docs/build-instructions/linux.md) in the section for Arch it says one should execute `sudo pacman -S --needed gconf base-devel git nodejs npm libgnome-keyring python2 libX11-devel libxkbfile-devel`, but the packages `libX11-devel`  and `libxkbfile-devel` don't exist in the Arch repos.
This can be tested by [searching for them on the Arch Website](https://www.archlinux.org/packages/?q=libX11-devel) or via pacman (`pacman -Ss libX11-devel`).
The the dependencies where added in the context of #12985.
However I could build Atom even without installing these packages. Maybe I already had installed the equivalents of these packages maybe they aren't even necessary on Arch.

data.title: atom.showSaveDialogSync broken in version 1.15.0
data.body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

-->

### Prerequisites

* [X] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=âœ“&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

`atom.showSaveDialogSync('some/chosen/path/to/file')` used to work (still worked in version 1.14.0) but doesn't work in version 1.15.0.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Open Atom in debug mode
2. Open console panel
3. Create a new file and edit something in the editor
4. In the console panel, type `atom.showSaveDialogSync('some/chosen/path/filename')`

**Expected behavior:** A save dialog pops out with the filename and path pre-set according to the param. 

**Actual behavior:** [What actually happens] The save dialog doesn't set to designated path and filename.

**Reproduces how often:** Always in version 1.15.0.

### Versions

Atom    : 1.15.0
Electron: 1.3.13
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.0

### Additional Information

Another example: 

This function is used in the Markdown Preview package (https://github.com/atom/markdown-preview/blob/master/lib/markdown-preview-view.coffee#L292). When the markdown preview pane is opened, right clicking on the preview and selecting "Save as HTML" used to lead to a popped out save dialog with the "Save As..." field auto-filled with a filename ending with ".html". But in version 1.15.0, the filename is just "Untitled".

data.title: :bug: Fix observation of moved items
data.body: `PaneContainer::onDidAddPaneItem` isn't triggered on moves.

data.title: Always add opened items to the workspace
data.body:
This commit changes the behavior of `open()` so that the item will be added to the workspaceâ€”even if the `activateItem` option is false.

This provides a way to open (and add) an item without activating it, but removes the ability to open without adding. For that, we've made the `createItemForURI()` method public ðŸ˜Š

### Alternate Designs

We also considered adding a new option (`addItem`). Ultimately, this approach was chosen instead because `createItemForURI()` avoids the extra searching machinery of `open()` which probably isn't desired when creating an item.

### Benefits

Now we can open items without focusing their tab.

### Possible Drawbacks

This is a breaking change so callers using `activateItem: false` may have to be updated. This seems to be exceedingly rare though.

data.title: Uncaught TypeError: Cannot read property 'paths' of undefined (while reopening a project)
data.body:
Steps:
1. I opened a new window from an existing Atom one using `File` â†’ `New Window`
2. I reopened a project through `File` â†’ `Reopen project`
3. Atom refuses to reopen with this error.

Also the `Reopen project` sub-menu is now empty (there was ~10 projects before).
I tried to open the project manually using `File` â†’ `Open Folder` and it worked, restoring the `Reopen project` sub-menu (don't ask me why).
I tried to switch to another project, close the bogus project then reopen it using the very same method and it worked, this second time.

I searched for similar issues but found none with a `paths`-related `TypeError`.

**Atom**: 1.15.0 x64
**Electron**: 1.4.15
**OS**: "Arch Linux"
**Thrown From**: Atom Core


### Stack Trace

Uncaught TypeError: Cannot read property 'paths' of undefined

```
At /usr/lib/atom/src/reopen-project-menu-manager.js:52

TypeError: Cannot read property 'paths' of undefined
    at ReopenProjectMenuManager.reopenProjectCommand (/usr/lib/atom/src/reopen-project-menu-manager.js:52:48)

    at EventEmitter.outerCallback (/usr/lib/atom/src/application-delegate.js:312:25)
    at emitThree (events.js:116:13)
    at EventEmitter.emit (events.js:194:7)
```

### Commands


data.title: Fixes #14102 to use ATOM_HOME if present.
data.body:
To test:

`$ ATOM_HOME=<some dir> ./scripts/build`

Check that outputs exist in that dir

`$ATOM_HOME=<some dir> ./scripts/clean`

Check that dir cleaned.

Repeat with no `ATOM_HOME` to check default home dir works

data.title: Add `atom.workspace.hide()`
data.body:
This adds an method for hiding items by URI and re-implements `toggle()` in terms of it. (tbh it's really just extracting most of  `toggle()` into a new function.)

cc @nathansobo @maxbrunsfeld

data.title: ATOM_HOME environment variable should be used in all build scripts when available.
data.body:
This follows on from #6349

There is currently an inconsistency with the the home directory that is used during execution of the build scripts.  Currently in the scripts, `ATOM_HOME` is not respected, however if `ATOM_HOME` is set during `scripts/build` `apm` uses that to place output into the dir specified.  So I can build Atom with an `ATOM_HOME` set but I can't clean that build because `scripts/clean` doesn't respect the var.

The solution is to fix https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/script/config.js#L18 to use `ATOM_HOME`, with the default to be `(HOME|USERPROFILE)\.atom`.

https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/script/lib/clean-caches.js#L11-L18 also needs to be updated to refer to `CONFIG.atomHomeDirPath`

This is tangentially related to #6345 in that USERPROFILE should not be used. However, in these cases you can't override the current behavior with an environment variable.

data.title: "The editor has crashed" - atom consistently crashes within 30 seconds of opening
data.body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

-->

### Prerequisites

* [X ] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/

### Description

I have been working on editing some SQL files and Atom keeps crashing whenever I open it up, even after following the steps from before. I have not installed any packages; it just breaks on me. I have reset my PC, reinstalled Atom, but still, constant crashing. I'm using 1.15 on Windows 7.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Open up Atom
2. See it crash and have the window pop up within 30 seconds

**Expected behavior:** [What you expect to happen]

**Actual behavior:** [What actually happens]

Reliable crashing

**Reproduces how often:** [What percentage of the time does it reproduce?]

100%

### Versions

1.15 on Windows 7

You can get this information from copy and pasting the output of `atom --version` and `apm --version` from the command line. Also, please include the OS and what version of the OS you're running.

### Additional Information

Any additional information, configuration or data that might be necessary to reproduce the issue.

### Stack Trace

TypeError: Cannot read property 'object' of undefined
    at ObjectsRegistry.get (D:\QQPCmgr\atom\app-1.15.0\resources\electron.asar\browser\objects-registry.js:41:28)

Atom 1.15.0

data.title: Don't snapshot minimatch and fix package transpilation registry on win32
data.body:
This module uses Node's `path` for determinining which path separator to use on the current platform. On browsers (and every other environment that does not support `require`, such as v8 snapshots) it falls back to always using a forward slash.

As a result, `PackageTranspilationRegistry` (and potentially other bundled packages that depend on `minimatch`) couldn't match glob expressions against any given path on Windows, thus causing the custom transpiler code to not work properly.

/cc: @BinaryMuse @smashwilson

data.title: penguin: Respect DISPLAY env variable in Unix like environments
data.body:
### Requirements

* Filling out the template is required. Any pull request that does not include enough information to be reviewed in a timely manner may be closed at the maintainers' discretion.
* All new code requires tests to ensure against regressions

Please advise on a test I can write. I have not been able to successfully compile HEAD so I'm not sure if I can test or if this code is complete. It is a small patch so feel free to just fork it. Note that I did manually test the concept by using the --socket-path option on startup and writing the socket path in the same way that it would be constructed in this code.

### Description of the Change

Atom connects to a socket to determine if it is already running
and if it should launch a new window in the same process.
This socket is named with the user's name but ignores the user's
display. If a user has multiple displays, such as running a
remote display server, Atom will pop up the new window on the display
that it was first started on.

This patch adds the display name to the socket name if it exists
in the env. Because a separate socket is being opened Atom does
the correct thing and launches on the display it was started on.

### Alternate Designs

No alternatives. On linux it should be using D-Bus to avoid these lifecycle/session issues but this is good enough with the benefit that it will work across different Unix like envs.

### Why Should This Be In Core?

Atom windows should open up on the display they are started on.

### Benefits

Users who remote into a different display (such as I have to do for work) will be able to start Atom without first stopping Atom processes running on a different display.

### Possible Drawbacks

None. This is proper behavior. Applications should always respect the environment they are started in.

### Applicable Issues

data.title: BrowserWindow events won't fire after reload
data.body:
### Description

In my init script I registered listerners to the "enter-full-screen" and "leave-full-screen" events on the [BrowserWindow](https://electron.atom.io/docs/api/browser-window/) object you get from atom::getCurrentWindow.
On the first start everything works as exspected but when I reload the window it doesn't work anymore. I also tried it with the events "maximize" and "focus". Same problem.
The rest of my init script still works after a reload.
I tried to reproduce it in safe mode. It looks like the init script isn't executed in safe mode, so I registered the listeners in the developer console. At first they worked but when I reload the window and it's the same problem again.
`atom --safe`, `atom --clear-window-state` and starting with a fresh user profile didn't help either.
There arn't any error messages in the developer console.
Since BrowserWindow is an Electron class I'm not sure if this is an Atom or Electron problem, but you're the same developer team anyway, right?

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Put this in your init script
    CoffeeScript
    ```coffee
    atom.getCurrentWindow().on "enter-full-screen", () ->
        alert "It works!"
    ```
    or JavaScript
    ```javascript
    atom.getCurrentWindow().on("enter-full-screen", function(){
        alert("It works!");
    });
    ```
2. Restart Atom to check if it works on the first start by going fullscreen (F11). Instead of using the init script and restarting you could also paste the JavaScript version into the developer console.
3. Reload with the command window:reload (Ctrl+Shift+F5). If you pasted the JavaScript version into the developer console do it again. Go fullscren.

**Expected behavior:** The listener should get called and a popup should appear.

**Actual behavior:** Nothing

**Reproduces how often:** Everytime

### Versions
```
atom --version
Atom		1.15.0
Electron	1.3.13
Chrome		52.0.2743.82
Node		6.5.0        

apm --version
apm		1.15.3
npm		3.10.5
node		4.4.5 ia32
python		2.7.13
git		2.12.2.
windowsvisual studio 2015
```

data.title: Color scheme getting crazy when concatenating loads of var. + strings in Python3
data.body:
* [X ] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=âœ“&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

When concatenating in Python 3 a high amount of content in my project, after a certain amount of quotations the color code stop working for some reason.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. [First Step] 
Create a .py file in atom
2. [Second Step] 
git clone my repo (where the problem appears) https://github.com/gustavohmsilva/Net-Claro-VOD-Manifest-Generator-Scripts.git
3. [Third Step]
Open the file CSVtoXML_Single.py in atom.
4. [Fourth Step]
Check how after some point on lines 127 and 152, this happens automatically, que color code just stop working and everything turns grey. On line 162, which is just a little bit smaller, the same doesn't happens.


**Expected behavior:** 
Color code should keep going like it would normally.

**Actual behavior:** 
Color code stop working and everything turns gray on that point forward (in that line, the next one is ok)

**Reproduces how often:** 
I'm concluding the third similar script and it always happens in long lines...

### Versions
1.15.0 x64 (running on mac os x sierra), but it also happened on the same version of atom in my Linux VM,  running Xubuntu 16.04 x64.

data.title: Link to Electron documentation when an Electron object is returned
data.body:
In the API Documentation [atom.getCurrentWindow()](https://atom.io/docs/api/v1.15.0/AtomEnvironment#instance-getCurrentWindow) is describend with "Get the current window".
No word about how to handle the returned object.
I found out that this object is an Electron [BrowserWindow](https://electron.atom.io/docs/api/browser-window/). I think it would be nice if there is an external link to the Electron documentation.
The same goes for any other case where a Electron object is returned.

data.title: Skipped tests in Jasmine spec runner
data.body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

-->

### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=âœ“&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

Show skipped tests (`xit`) in Jasmine spec runner

---

Running a test with `fit`
```coffeescript
fit "pass", ->
    expect(true).toEqual true
```
shows how many tests were performed and were skipped

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1185591/24452446/907109b0-1483-11e7-88dc-1d14eff17c5f.png)

But skipping some tests using `xit`
```coffeescript
xit "pass", ->
    expect(true).toEqual false
```
does not show how many tests were skipped

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1185591/24452543/13a71982-1484-11e7-8a96-c834f3bd5dd6.png)


### Steps to Reproduce

1. Skip a test in a package spec
2. Run package spec

**Expected behavior:** Show number of skipped tests using `xit`

**Actual behavior:** Does not show number of skipped tests using `xit`

**Reproduces how often:** 100%

### Versions

Windows7 x64, atom v1.16.0-beta0, apm v1.16.1

### Additional Information

Any additional information, configuration or data that might be necessary to reproduce the issue.
